title: Artificial Intelligence A Modern Approach, 1st Edition
author: Stuart Russell
description: Comprehensive, up-to-date introduction to the theory and practice of artificial intelligence. Number one in its field, this textbook is ideal for one or two-semester, undergraduate or graduate-level courses in Artificial Intelligence.

title: Learning Deep Architectures for AI
author: Yoshua Bengio
description: Foundations and Trends(r) in Machine Learning.

title: The LION Way: Machine Learning plus Intelligent Optimization
author: Roberto Battiti & Mauro Brunato
description: Learning and Intelligent Optimization (LION) is the combination of learning from data and optimization applied to solve complex and dynamic problems. Learn about increasing the automation level and connecting data directly to decisions and actions.

title: Disruptive Possibilities: How Big Data Changes Everything
author: Jeffrey Needham
description: This book provides an historically-informed overview through a wide range of topics, from the evolution of commodity supercomputing and the simplicity of big data technology, to the ways conventional clouds differ from Hadoop analytics clouds.

title: Computer Vision
author: Richard Szeliski
description: Challenging real-world applications where vision is being successfully used, both for specialized applications such as medical imaging, and for fun, consumer-level tasks such as image editing and stitching, which you can use on you own personal media

title: Natural Language Processing with Python
author: Steven Bird
description: This book offers a highly accessible introduction to natural language processing, the field that supports a variety of language technologies, from predictive text and email filtering to automatic summarization and translation.

title: Programming Computer Vision with Python
author: Jan Erik Solem
description: If you want a basic understanding of computer vision’s underlying theory and algorithms, this hands-on introduction is the ideal place to start. You’ll learn techniques for object recognition, 3D reconstruction, stereo imaging, augmented reality, etc

title: The Elements of Data Analytic Style
author: Jeff Leek
description: Data analysis is at least as much art as it is science. This book is focused on the details of data analysis that sometimes fall through the cracks in traditional statistics classes and textbooks.

title: A Course in Machine Learning
author: Hal Daumé III
description: None

title: A First Encounter with Machine Learning
author: Max Welling
description: None

title: Algorithms for Reinforcement Learning
author: Csaba Szepesvari
description: This book gives a very quick but still thorough introduction to reinforcement learning, and includes algorithms for quite a few methods. This is everything a graduate student could ask for in a text.

title: A Programmer's Guide to Data Mining
author: Ron Zacharski
description: A guide to practical data mining, collective intelligence, and building recommendation systems by Ron Zacharski. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons license.

title: Bayesian Reasoning and Machine Learning
author: David Barber
description: For final-year undergraduates and master's students with limited background in linear algebra and calculus. Comprehensive and coherent, it develops everything from basic reasoning to advanced techniques within the framework of graphical models.

title: Data Mining Algorithms In R
author: Wikibooks
description: None

title: Data Mining and Analysis: Fundamental Concepts and Algorithms
author: Mohammed J. Zaki & Wagner Meria Jr.
description: The main parts of the book include exploratory data analysis, pattern mining, clustering, and classification. The book lays the basic foundations of these tasks, and also covers many more cutting-edge data mining topics.

title: Data Mining: Practical Machine Learning Tools and Techniques
author: Ian H. Witten & Eibe Frank
description: Offers a thorough grounding in machine learning concepts as well as practical advice on applying machine learning tools and techniques in real-world data mining situations.

title: Data Mining with Rattle and R
author: Graham Williams
description: This book aims to get you into data mining quickly. Load some data (e.g., from a database) into the Rattle toolkit and within minutes you will have the data visualised and some models built.

title: Deep Learning
author: Yoshua Bengio, Ian J. Goodfellow, & Aaron Courville
description: The Deep Learning textbook is a resource intended to help students and practitioners enter the field of machine learning in general and deep learning in particular.

title: Gaussian Processes for Machine Learning
author: C. E. Rasmussen & C. K. I. Williams
description: A comprehensive and self-contained introduction to Gaussian processes, which provide a principled, practical, probabilistic approach to learning in kernel machines.

title: Information Theory, Inference, and Learning Algorithms
author: David J.C. MacKay
description: "Essential reading for students of electrical engineering and computer science; also a great heads-up for mathematics students concerning the subtlety of many commonsense questions." Choice

title: Introduction to Machine Learning
author: Amnon Shashua
description: None

title: Introduction to Machine Learning
author: Alex Smola & S.V.N. Vishwanathan
description: None

title: KB – Neural Data Mining with Python Sources
author: Roberto Bello
description: None

title: Machine Learning
author: Abdelhamid Mellouk & Abdennacer Chebira
description: None

title: Machine Learning, Neural and Statistical Classification
author: D. Michie, D.J. Spiegelhalter, & C.C. Taylor
description: None

title: Machine Learning – The Complete Guide
author: Wikipedia
description: None

title: Mining of Massive Datasets
author: Jure Leskovec, Anand Rajaraman, & Jeff Ullman
description: Essential reading for students and practitioners, this book focuses on practical algorithms used to solve key problems in data mining, with exercises suitable for students from the advanced undergraduate level and beyond.

title: Modeling With Data
author: Ben Klemens
description: Modeling with Data offers a useful blend of data-driven statistical methods and nuts-and-bolts guidance on implementing those methods. --Pat Hall, founder of Translation Creation

title: Neural Networks and Deep Learning
author: Michael Nielsen
description: Neural networks and deep learning currently provide the best solutions to many problems in image recognition, speech recognition, and natural language processing. This book will teach you concepts behind neural networks and deep learning.

title: Probabilistic Programming & Bayesian Methods for Hackers
author: Cam Davidson-Pilon
description: illuminates Bayesian inference through probabilistic programming with the powerful PyMC language and the closely related Python tools NumPy, SciPy, and Matplotlib. Using this approach, you can reach effective solutions in small increments.

title: Real-World Active Learning
author: Ted Cuzzillo
description: Applications and Strategies for Human-in-the-loop Machine Learning.

title: Reinforcement Learning: An Introduction
author: Richard S. Sutton & Andrew G. Barto
description: A clear and simple account of the key ideas and algorithms of reinforcement learning. Their discussion ranges from the history of the field's intellectual foundations to the most recent developments and applications.

title: Social Media Mining An Introduction
author: Reza Zafarani, Mohammad Ali Abbasi, & Huan Liu
description: Suitable for use in advanced undergraduate and beginning graduate courses as well as professional short courses, the text contains exercises of different degrees of difficulty that improve understanding and help apply concepts in social media mining

title: Theory and Applications for Advanced Text Mining
author: Shigeaki Sakurai
description: This book is composed of 9 chapters introducing advanced text mining techniques. They are various techniques from relation extraction to under or less resourced language.

title: Understanding Machine Learning: From Theory to Algorithms
author: Shai Shalev-Shwartz
description: The aim of this textbook is to introduce machine learning, and the algorithmic paradigms it offers, in a principled way.

title: An Introduction to Data Science
author: Jeffrey Stanton, Syracuse University
description: This book was developed for the Certificate of Data Science pro- gram at Syracuse University’s School of Information Studies.

title: Data Jujitsu: The Art of Turning Data into Product
author: DJ Patil
description: Learn how to use a problem's "weight" against itself. Learn more about the problems before starting on the solutions—and use the findings to solve them, or determine whether the problems are worth solving at all.

title: School of Data Handbook
author: School of Data
description: The School of Data Handbook is a companion text to the School of Data. Its function is something like a traditional textbook – it will provide the detail and background theory to support the School of Data courses and challenges.

title: The Art of Data Science
author: Roger D. Peng & Elizabeth Matsui
description: This book describes the process of analyzing data. The authors have extensive experience both managing data analysts and conducting their own data analyses, and this book is a distillation of their experience...

title: D3 Tips and Tricks
author: Malcolm Maclean
description: D3 Tips and Tricks is a book written to help those who may be unfamiliar with JavaScript or web page creation get started turning information into visualization.

title: Interactive Data Visualization for the Web
author: Scott Murray
description: Create and publish your own interactive data visualization projects on the Web—even if you have little or no experience with data visualization or web development. It’s easy and fun with this practical, hands-on introduction.

title: Data-Intensive Text Processing with MapReduce
author: Jimmy Lin & Chris Dyer
description: MapReduce [45] is a programming model for expressing distributed computations on massive amounts of data and an execution framework for large-scale data processing on clusters of commodity servers. It was originally developed by Google...

title: Hadoop Illuminated
author: Mark Kerzner & Sujee Maniyam
description: 'Hadoop illuminated' is the open source book about Apache Hadoop™. It aims to make Hadoop knowledge accessible to a wider audience, not just to the highly technical.

title: Hadoop Tutorial as a PDF
author: Tutorials Point
description: Intro to Hadoop - An open-source framework for storing and processing big data in a distributed environment across clusters of computers using simple programming models. It is designed to scale up from single servers to thousands of machines.

title: Programming Pig
author: Alan Gates
description: This guide is an ideal learning tool and reference for Apache Pig, the open source engine for executing parallel data flows on Hadoop.

title: Building Data Science Teams
author: DJ Patil
description: In this in-depth report, data scientist DJ Patil explains the skills,perspectives, tools and processes that position data science teams for success.

title: Data Driven: Creating a Data Culture
author: DJ Patil,‎ Hilary Mason
description: In this O’Reilly report, DJ Patil and Hilary Mason outline the steps you need to take if your company is to be truly data-driven—including the questions you should ask and the methods you should adopt.

title: The Data Science Handbook
author: by Carl Shan (Author),‎ William Chen (Author),‎ Henry Wang (Author),‎ Max Song (Author)
description: The Data Science Handbook is a compilation of in-depth interviews with 25 remarkable data scientists, where they share their insights, stories, and advice.

title: A Byte of Python
author: Swaroop C H
description: ‘A Byte of Python’ is a free book on programming using the Python language. It serves as a tutorial or guide to the Python language for a beginner audience. If all you know about computers is how to save text files, then this is the book for you.

title: Advanced R
author: Hadley Wickham
description: Useful tools and techniques for attacking many types of R programming problems, helping you avoid mistakes and dead ends. With ten+ years of experience programming in R, the author illustrates the elegance, beauty, and flexibility at the heart of R.

title: A Little Book of R for Time Series
author: Avril Coghlan
description: This is a simple introduction to time series analysis using the R statistics software.

title: Automate the Boring Stuff with Python: Practical Programming for Total Beginners
author: Al Sweigart
description: Practical programming for total beginners. In Automate the Boring Stuff with Python, you'll learn how to use Python to write programs that do in minutes what would take you hours to do by hand-no prior programming experience required.

title: Dive Into Python 3
author: Mark Pilgrim
description: This is a hands-on guide to Python 3 and its differences from Python 2. Each chapter starts with a real, complete code sample, picks it apart and explains the pieces, and then puts it all back together in a summary at the end.

title: Ecological Models and Data in R
author: Benjamin M. Bolker
description: The first truly practical introduction to modern statistical methods for ecology. In step-by-step detail, the book teaches ecology graduate students and researchers everything they need to know to analyze their own data using the R language.

title: Invent with Python
author: Albert Sweigart
description: "Invent Your Own Computer Games with Python" teaches you computer programming in the Python programming language. Each chapter gives you the complete source code for a new game and teaches the programming concepts from these examples.

title: Learning Statistics with R
author: Daniel Navarro
description: I (Dani) started teaching the introductory statistics class for psychology students offered at the University of Adelaide, using the R statistical package as the primary tool. These are my own notes for the class which were trans-coded to book form.

title: Learning with Python 3
author: Peter Wentworth, Jeffrey Elkner, Allen B. Downey, & Chris Meyers
description: Introduction to computer science using the Python programming language. It covers the basics of computer programming in the first part while later chapters cover basic algorithms and data structures.

title: Learn Python, Break Python
author: Scott Grant
description: This is a hands-on introduction to the Python programming language, written for people who have no experience with programming whatsoever. After all, everybody has to start somewhere.

title: Learn Python the Hard Way
author: Zed A. Shaw
description: This is a free sample of Learn Python 2 The Hard Way with 8 exercises and Appendix A available for you to review.

title: Practical Regression and Anova using R
author: Julian J. Faraway
description: This book is NOT introductory. The emphasis of this text is on the practice of regression and analysis of variance. The objective is to learn what methods are available and more importantly, when they should be applied.

title: Python for Everybody
author: Dr. Charles R Severance
description: This book is designed to introduce students to programming and computational thinking through the lens of exploring data. You can think of Python as your tool to solve problems that are far beyond the capability of a spreadsheet.

title: Python for You and Me
author: Kushal Das
description: This is a simple book to learn the Python programming language, it is for the programmers who are new to Python.

title: Python Practice Book
author: Anand Chitipothu
description: This book is prepared from the training notes of Anand Chitipothu.

title: Python Programming
author: Wikibooks
description: This book describes Python, an open-source general-purpose interpreted programming language available for a broad range of operating systems. This book describes primarily version 2, but does at times reference changes in version 3.

title: R by Example
author: Ajay Shah
description: None

title: R Programming
author: Wikibooks
description: The aim of this Wikibook is to be the place where anyone can share his or her knowledge and tricks on R. It is supposed to be organized by task but not by discipline. We try to make a cross-disciplinary book, i.e. a book that can be used by all.

title: R Programming for Data Science
author: Roger D. Peng
description: This book is about the fundamentals of R programming. You will get started with the basics of the language, learn how to manipulate datasets, how to write functions, and how to debug and optimize code.

title: Spatial Epidemiology Notes: Applications and Vignettes in R
author: Charles DiMaggio
description: My intent is to present a relatively brief, non-jargony overview of how practicing epidemiologists can apply some of the extremely powerful spatial analytic tools that are easily available to them.

title: The R Inferno
author: Patrick Burns
description: An essential guide to the trouble spots and oddities of R. In spite of the quirks exposed here, R is the best computing environment for most data analysis tasks.

title: The R Manuals
author: R Development Core Team
description: The R Manuals.

title: Think Python 2nd Edition
author: Allen Downey
description: This hands-on guide takes you through Python a step at a time, beginning with basic programming concepts before moving on to functions, recursion, data structures, and object-oriented design. Updated to Python 3.

title: A First Course in Linear Algebra
author: Robert A Beezer
description: This is an introduction to the basic concepts of linear algebra, along with an introduction to the techniques of formal mathematics. It has numerous worked examples, exercises and complete proofs, ideal for independent study.

title: Elementary Applied Topology
author: Robert Ghrist
description: This text gives a brisk and engaging introduction to the mathematics behind the recently established field of Applied Topology.

title: Elementary Differential Equations
author: William F. Trench
description: This text has been written in clear and accurate language that students can read and comprehend. The author has minimized the number of explicitly state theorems and definitions, in favor of dealing with concepts in a more conversational manner.

title: Introduction to Probability
author: Charles M. Grinstead & J. Laurie Snell
description: This book is designed for an introductory probability course at the university level for sophomores, juniors, and seniors in mathematics, physical and social sciences, engineering, and computer science.

title: Linear Algebra
author: David Cherney, Tom Denton & Andrew Waldron
description: None

title: Linear Algebra: An Introduction to Mathematical Discourse
author: Wikibooks
description: None

title: Linear Algebra, Theory And Applications
author: Kenneth Kuttler
description: This book gives a self- contained treatment of linear algebra with many of its most important applications. It is very unusual if not unique in being an elementary book which does not neglect arbitrary fields of scalars and the proofs of the theorems

title: Ordinary Differential Equations
author: Wikibooks
description: None

title: Probabilistic Models in the Study of Language
author: R Levy
description: None

title: Probability and Statistics Cookbook
author: Matthias Vallentin
description: The probability and statistics cookbook is a succinct representation of various topics in probability theory and statistics. It provides a comprehensive mathematical reference reduced to its essence, rather than aiming for elaborate explanations.

title: Cassandra Tutorial as a PDF
author: Tutorials Point
description: None

title: Extracting Data from NoSQL Databases
author: Petter Näsholm
description: None

title: Graph Databases
author: Ian Robinson, Jim Webber, & Emil Eifrem
description: Get started with O'Reilly's Graph Databases and discover how graph databases can help you manage and query highly connected data.

title: NoSQL Databases
author: Christof Strauch
description: None

title: SQL for Web Nerds
author: Philip Greenspun
description: None

title: SQL Tutorial as a PDF
author: Tutorials Point
description: This tutorial will give you a quick start to SQL. It covers most of the topics required for a basic understanding of SQL and to get a feel of how it works.

title: The Little MongoDB Book
author: Karl Seguin
description: MongoDB is an open source NoSQL database, easily scalable and high performance. It retains some similarities with relational databases which, in my opinion, makes it a great choice for anyone who is approaching the NoSQL world.

title: A First Course in Design and Analysis of Experiments
author: Gary W. Oehlert
description: Suitable for either a service course for non-statistics graduate students or for statistics majors. Unlike most texts for the one-term grad/upper level course on experimental design, this book offers a superb balance of both analysis and design.

title: An Introduction to Statistical Learning with Applications in R
author: Gareth James, Daniela Witten, Trevor Hastie, & Robert Tibshirani
description: This book presents some of the most important modeling and prediction techniques, along with relevant applications. Topics include linear regression, classification, resampling methods, shrinkage approaches, tree-based methods, and much more.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Foundations of Computational Agents
author: David Poole & Alan Mackworth
description: This is a textbook aimed at junior to senior undergraduate students and first-year graduate students. It presents artificial intelligence (AI) using a coherent framework to study the design of intelligent computational agents.

title: Intro Stat with Randomization and Simulation
author: David M Diez, Christopher D Barr, & Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel
description: The foundations for inference are provided using randomization and simulation methods. Once a solid foundation is formed, a transition is made to traditional approaches, where the normal and t distributions are used for hypothesis testing and...

title: OpenIntro Statistics
author: David M Diez, Christopher D Barr, & Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel
description: Probability is optional, inference is key, and we feature real data whenever possible. Files for the entire book are freely available at openintro.org.

title: The Elements of Statistical Learning: Data Mining, Inference, and Prediction
author: Trevor Hastie, Robert Tibshirani, & Jerome Friedman
description: This book describes the important ideas in a variety of fields such as medicine, biology, finance, and marketing in a common conceptual framework. While the approach is statistical, the emphasis is on concepts rather than mathematics.

title: Think Bayes: Bayesian Statistics Made Simple
author: Allen B. Downey
description: Think Bayes is an introduction to Bayesian statistics using computational methods. The premise of this book, and the other books in the Think X series, is that if you know how to program, you can use that skill to learn other topics.

title: Think Stats: Exploratory Data Analysis in Python
author: Allen B. Downey
description: This concise introduction shows you how to perform statistical analysis computationally, rather than mathematically, with programs written in Python.

title: Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning
author: Christopher M. Bishop
description: This is the first textbook on pattern recognition to present the Bayesian viewpoint. The book presents approximate inference algorithms that permit fast approximate answers in situations where exact answers are not feasible.
